results.title: The Enduring Wisdom of ‘Goodnight Moon’
results.abstract: It’s the first book many babies receive as a gift, and one of the few that parents will keep when their child is grown. Why does this 75-year-old story have such staying power?

results.adx_keywords: Birds;Animal Migration;Research;your-feed-science;Alaska;New Zealand
results.title: The Godwit’s Long, Long Nonstop Journey
results.abstract: Researchers marvel at the bird’s record-holding migratory flight of 7,000 or so miles from Alaska to New Zealand at this time of year. No eating or refueling along the way.

media.caption: Looking for an endless summer, the bar-tailed godwit flies 7,000 miles each year, from Alaska to New Zealand, to breed and raise its young.

results.byline: By Oliver Whang and Maddie McGarvey
results.title: A Rural Doctor Gave Her All. Then Her Heart Broke.
results.abstract: Physicians suffer one of the highest burnout rates among professionals. Dr. Kimberly Becher, one of two family practitioners in Clay County, West Virginia, learned the hard way.

media.caption: Dr. Kimberly Becher left a meeting at the Braxton County Health Department in Sutton, W. Va. in July. One of only two family doctors in the county, Dr. Becher was diagnosed with a stress-related heart condition during the pandemic.

results.byline: By Rachel Sugar and Jane Dickson
results.title: For New Yorkers, 6 p.m. Is the New 8 p.m.
results.abstract: Why are restaurants in the city filling up at hours that were once unfashionably early?

media.caption: Jane Dickson’s “Odeon” (2022). Since the 1970s, for her series “Times Square & the City at Night,” the New York-based artist has depicted iconic venues and their signage by visiting them after dark; for this version, made exclusively for T, she stopped by the Odeon in TriBeCa during its now-bustling twilight hours.

results.title: Mississippi Lifts Boil Advisory in Jackson, but Its Water System Remains Troubled
results.abstract: Health authorities issued the boil-water notice in late July, when testing showed the water supply might be unsafe, and heavy rains in August caused the largest treatment plant in the system to fail.

media.caption: Terun Moore, 42, left, distributed water in August to residents of Jackson, Miss. More than 150,000 people there, as well as residents of surrounding counties, have been under a boil-water advisory.
